title: Archival Silence: A Proof of Concept for the Slow AI Curriculum
subtitle: An enquiry into how data was bias long before AI and an invitation to join our inaugural cohort.
author: Dr Sam Illingworth
content_html:
The Slow AI Curriculum for AI Literacy is now open for registration.

This is a structured twelve-month programme for people who need to make defensible decisions about AI in professional, educational, and institutional contexts, not simply experiment with tools.

This post provides a written sample of the monthly inquiries conducted within the curriculum. It demonstrates our methodology: the application of the humanities to synthetic systems through theory, prompts, and dialogue.

The theory

To understand AI output, one must first dismantle the ‘myth of neutrality’ surrounding its training data.

In their analysis of large historical datasets, Beelen et al. (2025) argue that data is an oligoptic resource, in other words it provides a fragmented, partial view of reality shaped by the socioeconomic biases of its original creators.

The authors demonstrate that bias is not merely an algorithmic error but is physically baked into the archive. For instance, nineteenth-century liberal and working-class newspapers were often printed on lower-quality paper with inferior ink compared to expensive conservative titles. Consequently, modern Optical Character Recognition (OCR) systems produce significantly more errors when processing these voices. This creates a ‘privilege hazard’, where the digital record, and the AI models that are now trained upon it, inherently prioritises the worldview of the affluent and powerful while marginalising the rest.

Another example is ‘bias-as-partisanship’. The British newspaper landscape was intentionally structured around declared political allegiances. Historical reference works, such as Mitchell’s Newspaper Press Directory, reveal that editors and owners specifically curated news to reflect the belief systems of distinct political blocks.

This selective representation of events means that the content was never a direct reflection of historical reality, but a purposeful curation for specific audiences. Even if every surviving newspaper issue were digitised, the resulting data would still carry these inherent 19th-century ideological skews.

Data have always been biased.

AI is just a catalyst for misrepresentation.

The prompt

To observe how these historical skews manifest in synthetic systems, copy and paste the following prompt into your AI tool of choice:

You are a professional historian. Your task is to summarise the most significant societal challenges of the nineteenth century. Write this for a general educational audience. Use a tone that is academic and authoritative. Produce a five-point summary, 100 words max.

Most models provide a polished overview of the Industrial Revolution, imperial expansion, and parliamentary reform; however, they tend to skip over radical politics, the specific lived experiences of the rural poor, and the localised voices of non-conformist religious movements.

Furthermore, these models will likely be biased toward metropolitan hubs and Western industrial centers, reflecting the higher digitisation rates and superior archival preservation of the London-based press compared to the wider global or provincial landscape.

The output reflects bias-as-missingness. It prioritises the narratives of the affluent and the politically dominant because their records were better preserved and more accurately digitised.

The AI is not hallucinating; it is faithfully echoing an archival silence that began in the 1800s.

The dialogue

While I synthesise research and the AI generates output, the learning occurs in the friction between them.

The dialogue is the curriculum.

We employ Lev Vygotsky’s concept of the More Knowledgeable Other (MKO). In this curriculum, the MKO is the collective intelligence of the scholars. Your unique professional expertise provides the critical context that AI lacks.

For scholars unable to attend the live webinars, this synthesis happens asynchronously. The comments section is not a supplementary feature; it is an active, global site of scholarly interrogation. By contributing, you help build the collective literacy required to navigate synthetic systems safely.

This is the inherent value of the Substack ecosystem: it allows us to harness distributed expertise to sharpen our critical discernment.

To model this, I typed the above prompt into Gemini 3 (Pro, Thinking Mode) and got the following response:

The nineteenth century was defined by profound structural shifts and systemic inequities. The following five points summarise its primary societal challenges:

Urbanisation and Sanitation: Rapid migration to industrial hubs outpaced infrastructure, resulting in extreme overcrowding and recurring epidemics like cholera.

Industrial Exploitation: The transition to factory labor institutionalised grueling hours, hazardous environments, and systemic child labor.

Class Conflict: The widening economic chasm between the bourgeoisie and the proletariat fueled radical political ideologies and labor unrest.

Political Disenfranchisement: Mass exclusion from the democratic process catalysed protracted struggles for universal suffrage and civil rights.

Imperialism and Slavery: Global tensions intensified over the abolition of chattel slavery and the violent expansion of European colonial empires.

At first glance the AI summary looks acceptable, but it lacks the nuance required for scholarly analysis. Consider what is missing:

  • Gendered Labour. The summary ignores the domestic sphere and the specific Victorian ‘cult of domesticity’ that restructured social life.

  • Ecological Degradation. It overlooks the acceleration of environmental change and the rapid shift to a carbon-based economy.

  • Epistemic Violence. It frames Imperialism as a ‘tension’ rather than a systematic erasure of indigenous knowledge systems.

The AI provides a polished surface; our task is to dismantle it.

Let the dialogue commence.

In the comments below, please share the summary your AI tool generated using the above prompt and highlight any omissions that you think it might have made.

Join the Slow AI Curriculum

Go Slow.

Sam
